comments.commentBody:
The FICA rates for 2016 are 7.65% employee, 7.65% employer and 15.3% self-employed.

Republicans hate Social Security because this is the only tax which business cannot dodge. Employees may dislike paying this tax, but at least employees will eventually draw benefits. For business, there is no up-side.

Reforming Social Security doesn't have anything to do with saving the system. It's all about business dodging social responsibility and boosting the bottom line. Grow old? That's YOUR problem.

This editorial misses the mark and is far too restrained in its message.

First of all, absolutely nothing Trump has stated during the campaign carries any weight or meaning. He has changed most of his positions 180 degrees at the drop of a hat. How many times do we have to witness this behavior before it is officially recognized by the media?

Secondly, Trump does what pleases his immediate audience. With his appointments, he has surrounded himself with the most right wing, anti-government people available. They are the most anti-labor, anti-environment, anti-healthcare, anti-regulation, anti-tax, anti-education bunch of right wingers imaginable. What all of them want to do is cut spending. They live for reducing federal spending. It's all on the chopping block. With the appointment of Mulvaney, the axe wielding budget executioner is in place and ready to chop away.

Thirdly, Paul von Voucher Ryan is absolutely giddy. He is so happy that he will finally get to do what he has always wanted more than anything. He wants to be the guy that voucherizes federal entitlement spending. Trump will fall for it.

So the gross error here is not in recognizing that Social Security is on the block. First will come Medicaid aid because its beneficiaries are the weakest. Then Medicare and the last to go will be Social Security.

All of it is on the block and all will be cut. We now have a Czar, Donny the Terrible, in charge and he doesn't have a clue what he is doing.

Cutting Social Security or Medicare will the GOP's ticket right out of Washington by 2018, if not 2020 - at the latest.

I wanna run against a GOP that cuts marginal rates on the Trumps and Adelsons of the world while gutting Social Security, Medicare, and the rest of the safety net.

Make the election of 2020 the biggest rout in American history - and then watch us reverse every change they make, and reestablish both programs on infinitely stronger ground.

Mess with the 3rd rail of American politics, and watch the entire GOP end up out of office, and with hair like the guy from Ancient Aliens.

Upper income earners should be required to pay payroll taxes on much more of their income. That said, I am not in favor of much means testing for actual benefits. One of the things that makes the program work is that everyone is part of it. If it comes to be viewed as simply another government program for low income folks, there is likely, over time, to be less support for the program by the middle and upper classes.

The article does not mention the GOP wish to "privatize" Social Security, but that too is a danger. In theory it sounds lovely to let the people manage more of their own money. However, when the stock market takes a header many folks are at best uncertain and at worst panic and pull their money out. Only the well off or relatively so would have the needed access to good investment advice and hand-holding. Many folks with less knowledge, less access to help would struggle to do the best with their money. They are the folks who will most need those benefits.

The hen house will become a "fox" house if The Con Don is allowed to take the presidency in January.

The Con Don and his Democracy-Destroying Top 1% Global Financial Elite Exploit-Extract Robber Baron Party - including fox so-called news king Rupert Murdoch - will make out like the Robber Barons they are. One of their main goals has been to get the HUGE pot of money that goes into OUR Social Security accounts with every single paycheck onto the stock market so they can get their hands on it, manipulate it and pocket it.

For a primer on how to steal from the American public I suggest people go to Wikipedia and look up George Bush Sr., Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to see how adroitly Reagan/Bush then Bush turned government money into stock market money through the two agencies, which led to the 2008 crash. At the same time they took away average people's rights and social safeguards and raised OUR taxes. This time around will be on steroids because they have mastered the art.

Are we going to let these insatiably greedy, power-at-all-costs, socially unconscious group of Robber Barons destroy OUR world?

Only WE average people at grassroots level around the world can stop them by actively, vigorously opposing them at every turn. That includes those people in government and business who know what is going on - YOU must be extremely loud whistle blowers to let the rest of us know what is happening inside so WE can stop it before it gets traction. Obstruct, Obstruct, Obstruct.

Trump is not non-ideological. He is a hard right conservative who used populist rhetoric to "win" the election. So, Social Security is no sacred cow to him. On the other hand, he made a big pledge on a big stage not to cut Social Security and Medicare. If he goes back on that pledge, it will be like GHW Bush reversing his "no new tax pledge." It will haunt him for the rest of his presidency, and I suspect will make it impossible for him to win reelection (if free and fair) in 2020. It will also dog the Republican Party in general in the 2018 midterms. For these reasons, I suspect that he might not go along with the plans to cut Social Security and Medicare.

The only actual issue: Which alternative will more likely promote Mr. Trump's self interest?

(A) Trump's thorough detente with the GOP establishment.

(B) Trump's fidelity to his campaign "promise" to keep Social Security as is.

Since his "promise" has already served its purpose, I suspect (A) will be Trump's chosen alternative.

At his victory rallies, he has told his common-folk supporters that he no longer needs their vote. He has been elected, after all. He added, by way of an after-thought, that he will need those votes again in another four years. But in another four years he will have leveraged the power and the prestige of the U.S. presidency for most all that it's worth.

In four years, Trump and his family will be stuffing their saddlebags with gold and riding off into the sunset.

It is of course entirely possible that one of the younger Trump's will want to keep the political dynasty going. In that case, if the narcissistic Mr. Trump views establishing a political dynasty as somehow promoting his own self-interest, he just might keep some of his promises to those "little-people-losers" who helped elect him.

Money or political power or the continued dynastic possession of both? Which will best serve the Trump family's interests?

Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell have both long been salivating at the prospect of cutting Social Security. They have both failed to walk away from Trump for the hopes of Trump enacting their agenda. And they will both have a receptive ear in Mike Pence.
Social Security is one of the first prices to pay for having Republicans in control of everything.

The NYT editorial board's recommendation to decrease the SSI payments to those who paid at the highest income levels taxed (currently $118K in wage income) is absurd given that this group currently is paid back much less on a per dollar contributed level than any other group. Are those upper-middle class wage earners to be penalized further simple because they worked hard, followed the society's rules and tend to take their health and welfare seriously?  IMO, The answer to SSI funding is simple - remove the SSI wage cap entirely, and the problems is solved. Speaking from fist-hand experience, once one is earning above the $118K level in annual wages, the 6.2% SSI tax is not that onerous, and is part of the American's compact between generations.

Of course, slashing or killing Social Security and Medicare would be a perfectly horrible and cruel thing to do to this country. It would be terrible for retirees, for struggling families that would need to support aging family members, and it would put a big dent in our consumer economy. What a really stupid and mean idea! On those grounds alone, Trump will do it, or let the Republicans do it.

However, should this occur, then we must end the retirement and generous health benefits for the President, cabinet officers, and the members of the House and Senate. For what they currently receive, see: http://www.aarp.org/work/employee-benefits/info-12-2010/benefits_what_do...

The quickest way to almost guarantee a Democratic Congress in 2019 would be to slash Social Security. No matter what rhetoric you hear from someone of retirement age or near retirement age, everyone loves a little socialism when it's their turn to be the beneficiary.

There's never any question about whether older people will show up at the polls, either.

My guess is that the House will come up with some draconian plan for Social Security ( like the one on the table now ), and then the Donald will come in a save the day by making it less draconian...and then fly around the country and hold rallies where he tells everyone how he saved Social Security.  I read the proposed bill the other day, and didn't see where it addressed the real problem with Social Security...Social Security Disability.  In some states (ones that Trump carried) it had become the new unemployment.
I would gladly give up all my Social Security benifit in order to cut the taxes on God's chosen people, the Real American Oligarchs, blessed be their tax deductible vacation homes.

I will not be surprised if Trump caves and I will not be surprised if his supporters show no outrage. After reading Arlie Hochschild's Strangers in Their Own Land, I understand that Trump supporters are willing to get cancer from a polluted environment, have underfunded schools, no health care and live their final years in poverty (among other things) just so those "behind them in line" don't cut ahead, ie. get benefits. I now believe the most important lesson my parents taught me was "don't cut off your nose to spite your face." It is clear to me that Trump supporters are more than willing to cut off their eyes, ears, noses and a few limbs, as long as it means "those people" behind them will continue to be worse off.  What can we do?

The NYT Editorial Board is falling into the Republican trap when they tell us "A prudent approach to reform would target the causes of the system’s shortfall with a mix of modest benefit cuts and modest tax increases." The prudent approach to reform should target the system's shortfall with modest tax increases. Period.

The fact of the matter is that a modest benefit cut that extends the eligibility age for full Social Security benefits to age 69 is not a modest benefit cut, it is the theft of two years of Social Security benefits. If you use the average annual Social Security benefit of $16,000, then retirees are losing $32,000 at the beginning of their retirement.

If the Republicans are so enamored of extending the eligibility age for Social Security or Medicare benefits, I recommend the same extension be applied to the receipt of salary benefits for Members of Congress and all federal political appointees every time they come up with another scheme the involves the picking of pockets of working and retired Americans. I also recommend requiring the repayment the $270 billion dollars they borrowed from the SSA trust fund before any benefit cuts are implemented.

I am a 62 year old woman whose financial plan included receiving Social Security benefits at my retirement age, 66.   My financial plan had allowed me to live off of my IRA until my retirement age to collect my full benefit.  I, like many others in my situation, have paid Social Security taxes for more than 45 years.  Now  my financial adviser is recommending that I take my Social Security early, at age 63.  I would receive a difference in $500 a month for early retirement, but, supposedly, if I am already in the system receiving benefits, the cuts will not be as severe.  Interestingly, my adviser with Fidelity said he had submitted several suggestions for easy fixes to the Social Security funding problem, but they were unheeded.  I have no confidence in any pledges trump has made.  I do believe, as horrifying as this is, that trump will do only whatever profits him.

As much as I dislike Donald Trump, it's sobering to think he may be the only thing between us and the Paul Ryan radical right wing Republicans in Congress. Not that the privatization scheme hasn't been proposed before - I think Bush wanted to try it. This faction of the Republican party is just brazen and shameless in proposing anti-government policies, tax cuts for corporations and wealthy, taking away health insurance from millions of people, etc. We can only hope Trump does stand up to Congress on certain issues, although unfortunately his early Cabinet picks suggest he will kowtow to the far right. If he cannot bring higher paying jobs for less-skilled workers back, maybe those disaffected working class voters will repudiate Republicans at the state and national levels in another two years.
Did anyone think to ask him in between the chants of "lock her up"? Of course he is going along on the cuts. And a whole lot more.

Some rich fat cat sitting in an office can work as long as he wants. The manual and outdoor laborers do NOT have this option. I wish these "bright" idea republicans would walk a mile in another's shoes. The whole bunch needs to be turned out and get off their government dole.
I am a big trump supporter but if he allows cuts to medicare and social security he will not get my vote next time.

@Matthew

Oh, how I wish you were right, but I fear your prognostications are yet another refrain of "the American people will finally wake up."

They are not sleeping, they are in an irreversible coma.

Guns or butter? At our current rate of taxation we can't simultaneously support the world's most formidable military and provide health and retirement benefits for those at the bottom of the income distribution. The top 1% don't have boots in Afghanistan or Iraq, their boot are on the beach or golf course.

Support the troops, suckers.

To all you low wage workers who acted out your "resentment" and voted for Trump and his merry band of Republican robber barons, your votes will soon be rewarded with cuts to, and ultimately destruction of, Social Security, Medicare & Medicaid. Meanwhile, the top one percent will get more tax cuts and more tax shelters. You have been punked. Welcome to Putin's Russia, American style.

It is a mystery. Why would the GOP, an American political party, work so hard to avoid helping other Americans? Like the man who poisons his own well because his neighbor looks thirsty, they cannot abide a tax which benefits someone else even when they themselves benefit e.g., Social Security. Social Security can be fixed but it means getting the GOP to go to the well along with all their fellow Americans. For some reason, that's hard for the GOP to swallow.
